html:
A conversation around tomato plants taught me more than a TED talk on design ever could.

Last week, I had lunch with a man who once managed over 1,000 designers across multiple continents. He is the kind of design leader who doesn’t just do design, but he lives it. Ideas poured out of him that were wild, unpredictable, and brilliantly creative. He has won some of the top global awards. We have had conversations about creativity, and he has always shared valuable insights from his lived experience, which no book can provide. He was the kind of boss you brag about.

So naturally, over a tasty south Indian lunch and melodious sitar music, I asked him the usual: “What do you think about design now? About AI, disruption, where the industry’s going?”

He looked up, smiled gently, and said, “Honestly? I’m more worried about my tomato plants these days.

That hit me harder than any TED keynote.

And just like that, my brain short-circuited. The pests, weeds, and that damned squirrel occupied his mind instead of UX, Figma, or AGI.

I was expecting a monologue on AI, agents, and the automation of jobs. You spend your life obsessed with the pixel…
